block.p: Israel Extends Ultimatum, As Cabinet Weighs Options Prime Minister Ehud Barak's deadline for the Palestinians to end violent protests expired with riots still raging, but the Israeli cabinet said it would give the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, more time. As anxiety rose that the conflict might escalate and spread, an international intervention effort intensified with the arrival of the United Nations secretary general and Russia's foreign minister. President Clinton was expected to decide soon whether to call an emergency summit meeting.
President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt held a two-hour meeting in Cairo with Mr. Arafat.

Israel Extends Ultimatum, As Cabinet Weighs Options Prime Minister Ehud Barak's deadline for the Palestinians to end violent protests expired with riots still raging, but the Israeli cabinet said it would give the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, more time. As anxiety rose that the conflict might escalate and spread, an international intervention effort intensified with the arrival of the United Nations secretary general and Russia's foreign minister. President Clinton was expected to decide soon whether to call an emergency summit meeting.
President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt held a two-hour meeting in Cairo with Mr. Arafat.

Several hundred Jews in Nazareth left a Jewish enclave and rampaged, apparently leading to the killings of two Arabs by the Israeli police and a spate of revenge attacks by Arab residents of the mostly Arab city.

Hezbollah's capture of three Israeli soldiers along the Lebanese border on Saturday was a well-planned operation, leaders of the guerrilla group and military experts said. Hezbollah's immediate goal, they said, was to swap the three sergeants for 19 jailed Islamic militants.

Timor Refugees Tell of Terror People who have fled from defeated East Timorese militias that have regrouped in West Timor say the militias are tightening their grip in the absence of a foreign presence.

Milosevic Allies Resign Prime Minister Momir Bulatovic of Yugoslavia and Interior Minister Vlajko Stojiljkovic, who controlled the Serbian police, resigned under pressure from supporters of the new president, Vojislav Kostunica. The resignations were followed by the announcement of early elections to the Serbian Parliament.
The European Union eased sanctions and pledged $2 billion to rebuild Yugoslavia's infrastructure.

New Evidence in Lockerbie Trial A delay was granted in the Pan Am Flight 103 bombing trial after prosecutors announced that there was new evidence ''of some complexity and considerable sensitivity'' that they needed time to consider.

Conservative Reversal on Drugs The Conservative Party leader, William Hague, abandoned a new hard-line policy on first-time drug offenders after seven leadership associates said they had smoked marijuana in their youth. The proposal, put forward at the party's conference last week, called for $150 minimum fines and criminal records for people caught with small amounts of soft drugs.

Zimbabwe Lawmakers Arrested Three opposition members of Parliament were arrested on charges of inciting violence, and supporters were sprayed with tear gas. The arrests come two months after President Robert Mugabe bowed to election results and welcomed an opposition into the Parliament for the first time with promises of cooperation.

Fight to Control House Is Seen Be to Narrowing About 24 Republican House seats seem to be vulnerable, while 10 or fewer are in play on the Democratic side, a change in about 8 seats favoring the Democrats. That hardly guarantees the net gain of seven that the Democrats need for a majority, but it puts it in reach.

Preparing for Next Debate Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush stayed largely sequestered as they prepared for the second of their three scheduled nationally televised debates, tomorrow night in Winston-Salem, N.C.

Dick Cheney has come under sharp criticism from conservatives in the Republican Party for comments they regard as supportive of gay marriage that he made during his debate last week with his Democratic rival, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman.

Campaign Mole Inquiry Federal prosecutors have subpoenaed records from Gov. George W. Bush's presidential campaign and its media consulting firm to determine whether either played any role in mailing confidential Bush debate materials last month to an associate of Vice President Al Gore, law enforcement officials and Bush campaign officials said.

Efforts to Reshape Education Voters around the country will consider a record number of education questions on state ballots next month, including whether to offer private school vouchers to parents, shut down bilingual classrooms, pay teachers based on student performance and sharply limit discussion of homosexuality in the classroom.
In Alaska, voters will be asked to consider Proposition 5, the broadest marijuana legalization initiative ever to appear on a state ballot.

Ex-C.I.A. Chief's Missing Files Pentagon investigators have been unable to locate computer disks on which a former director of central intelligence, John M. Deutch, stored a journal containing classified information while he was working at the Defense Department. Mr. Deutch has declined to be interviewed about the whereabouts of the disks. C.I.A. officials have concluded that he improperly recorded secrets in a private journal, and the Justice Department is investigating whether criminal charges are warranted.

Ex-Transit Chief Takes On London's Ailing Subway London officials said they had hired an American, Robert R. Kiley, who helped rebuild the New York subway in the 1980's, to fix the problems of the London subway system. Mr. Kiley, M.T.A. chairman from 1983 to 1990, will become commissioner of a new London agency that will oversee subway operations as well as bus service, taxis, traffic lights, ferries and some light rail and roads.

Missing Flight Attendant The coroner in Boise, Idaho, tentatively identified a body found in the Boise River as that of a United Airlines flight attendant from Long Island, Lynn Henneman, 38, who was last seen on Sept. 24. The police called the death a homicide.

Graffiti Arrests at Gallery The police used a graffiti exhibition at Deitch Projects gallery in Soho to arrest artists in the show for work they once spray-painted on city streets. The gallery owner said he was stunned by the police action.
Yanks-Mariners Series Begins The Yankees and the Seattle Mariners open their four-of-seven-game American League Championship Series tonight at Yankee Stadium.

3 Share Nobel Prize Dr. Arvid Carlsson of Sweden, and two New Yorkers, Dr. Eric R. Kandel of Columbia and Dr. Paul Greengard of Rockefeller University, received the Prize for Physiology and Medicine for their work on understanding long-term changes in the brain that underlie memory and mood.
John T. Connor A commerce secretary in the Johnson administration and a former chief executive of Merck & Company and Allied Chemical, he was 85.

Americans Keep On Truckin' Despite rising fuel prices, few people have sharply cut back on driving or begun shopping for cars based mainly on fuel efficiency, and the nation is on pace to use almost the same amount of gas as it did last year, which was the most ever. Sport utility vehicles and other trucks continue to gain market share.

Japan Insurance Bankruptcy Chiyoda Mutual Life Insurance, one of Japan's largest insurers, filed for bankruptcy protection after the government failed to force other financial institutions to throw a lifeline to Chiyoda, which has nearly $27 billion in liabilities.

Higher Bid for Airline Assets Continental Airlines offered to pay $215 million for the assets that US Airways Group plans to spin off in Washington as part of its proposed purchase by the parent of United Airlines. The price easily exceeds the $141 million offer from Robert Johnson, a member of the US Airways board and the founder of Black Entertainment Television, who wants to create a carrier called DC Air.
Stocks Meander on Slow Day Major stock averages edged downward in light holiday trading.
